Dear Brandon Hannah:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(iii)Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or
otherwise suggesting physical or emotional harm to a
youth
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 1/29/23, a youth and a staff member engaged in a verbal
argument in which they threatened to physically assault each
other.
Investigation Youth B was interviewed on 01/31/2023 during an unannounced
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated that she had been
involved in an altercation with Staff 1 the Sunday prior. Youth B
stated that everything occurred during the bedtime portion of the
evening when youth were getting into bed and supposed to have
“low tones” and not be speaking. She recalled other youth talking
and being somewhat disruptive and remembered hearing Staff 1
state “I don’t even like this fucking unit” while interacting with the
other youth. Youth B admitted that she began to sing and talk
with other youth when she was not supposed to and stated that
she and Staff 1 began to escalate together. Youth B stated that
she heard Staff 1 say to her “You ain’t gonna do shit” and “I’ll beat
your mother fucking ass” to her. Youth B stated that they both
threatened each other as this conversation continued. Youth B
recalled getting more and more upset at Staff 1 and admitted to
coming at her in an attempt to hurt Staff 1. Youth B stated that
she was able to grab on to Staff 1’s hair briefly only to have
Supervisor 1 intervene between them and attempt to restrain her.
Youth B recalled Supervisor 1 asking Staff 1 to leave the unit and
she did. Youth B recalled the restraint as being “by the book” and
she stated that she understood why she was restrained. She
stated that Supervisor 1 had grabbed her arms right above the
wrists in and called for Staff 2 to assist and did not attempt to take
her to the ground. Before Staff 2 could assist, Youth B stated that
she was still trying to get to and hit Staff 1 and in doing so she
twisted her knee and fell to the ground. It was Youth B’s opinion
that this all happened within seconds and that Supervisor 1 didn’t
do anything wrong in the process. Youth B stated that Staff 1 was
outside the unit when she fell and that Supervisor 1 and another
2

staff she could not remember immediately turned their attention
towards helping her up and addressing her knee pain.
Youth A/Complainant, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E were spoken
to separately during the same unannounced face-to-face visit to
the facility on 01/31/2023. Youth F was spoken to on 02/10/2023
during an announced visit to the facility. All five-youth recalled
similar elements of what occurred during the incident between
Youth B and Staff 1. Each youth believed that Staff 1 could have
better attempted to de-escalate Youth B and antagonized her.
Youth A stated that she heard Staff 1 state “shut the fuck up
talking to me” directed at Youth B. Youth D stated that she heard
Staff 1 state “I told you to be quiet, but that is what you gonna do,
shut the fuck up.” She also stated that she heard Staff 1 remark
“go ahead, go ahead, you ain’t gonna do nothing” in response to
Youth B threatening Staff 1. Youth F stated that she heard similar
things and also heard Staff 1 state that she was going to “beat
your ass back” to Youth B before Youth B approached her. All
five-youth presented similar recollections of Youth B escalating
and eventually approaching Staff 1 and attempting to pull Staff 1’s
hair. They all stated that Supervisor 1 intervened at that point and
asked Staff 1 to leave the unit in an attempt to de-escalate the
situation, which she promptly did.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone on 02/06/2023. She
stated that she recalled the incident in question. She believed that
Sunday evening was her first day back at work after some time off
and that she was assigned to Unit 4 when she normally does not
work with them. Staff 1 remarked that she knew that unit of girls
struggled greatly and that she had heard the night before went
poorly and wished she did not have to work in that unit with them.
Staff 1 recalled several of the youth in the unit being loud at
bedtime when they were supposed to have “low tones” and be
quiet. Staff 1 stated that she was trying very hard to take a “light”
tone when speaking with the youth at that point because “you
know what happens when you don’t”, referring to allegations being
made against staff any time they challenge youth. Staff 1 stated
that at one point she heard Youth B state “We just trying to be bad
tonight” to another youth. Staff 1 recalled just being repetitive at
that point, addressing the youth by asking them not to cuss and
keep their tones down when they should not have been talking at
all. Staff 1 stated that everything began to escalate more at about
9:30 pm. When addressed further to quiet down Staff 1 stated
that Youth B remarked back “Fuck all the staff” and began to raise
her voice. She then heard Youth B state directly to her “I ain’t
gonna listen to no bitch.” Staff 1 stated that Supervisor 1 came
3

into the unit upon her alerting him over walkie talkie at about that
time, and then Youth B proceeded to run up to Staff 1 and try to
attack her. Staff 1 stated that Youth B was able to get her hands
over Supervisor 1 briefly and try to grab her, but that Supervisor
1’s intervention and Staff 1 moving backwards allowed this to be
brief and largely unsuccessful. Staff 1 stated that Supervisor 1
had told her to leave the unit at that point and she did so. She
stated that she did not witness Youth B’s restraint or any other
interactions at that point and for the rest of her shift as she did not
return to that unit. Staff 1 noted several times during the interview
that she knew allegations would be coming and that she never
had any attitude towards any of the youth that evening. She
denied ever threatening Youth B or using any inappropriate
language of any form.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed over the phone on 03/01/2023. He
stated that he was present the night of the incident between Youth
B and Staff 1. Supervisor 1 recalled being alerted to an escalating
situation in Youth B’s unit by Staff 1 over the radio and he
responded as quickly as he could. As soon as he came into the
unit he heard Youth B yelling loudly and threatening Staff 1.
Supervisor 1 stated that he didn't hear Staff 1 say much of
anything at that point. Very quickly upon entering the unit
Supervisor 1 had to get in front of an advancing Youth B as she
tried to attack Staff 1. Supervisor 1 stated that he didn’t believe
Youth B was able to harm Staff 1 much as he had told Staff 1 to
leave the unit immediately and she did so. Supervisor 1 recalled
that as Staff 1 was leaving he had both of his hands on Youth B’s
wrists in an attempt to prevent her from getting to Staff 1. At that
time he asked Staff 2 to assist him in attempting a standing
restraint as they are trained. Supervisor 1 recalled that Youth B
then tried to get past him and in doing so she twisted her knee
and slowly went to the ground. Supervisor 1 stated that this all
was pretty much one motion and that as soon as he realized
Youth B was not attempting to get outside to Staff 1 and that she
may be hurt he released his hands of her. At that point Supervisor
1 stated that Staff 2 was at his side and they started tending to
Youth B and her knee pain, and she was compliant and calm.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone on 03/07/2023. He stated
he entered the unit when Youth B was already escalated and
didn’t hear Staff 1 say anything inappropriate when he was
present. Staff 1 left the unit shortly after being told to do so by
Supervisor 1. Staff 2 stated that he was by Supervisor 1’s side as
he attempted to prevent Youth B from getting to Staff 1. Staff 2
recalled that Supervisor 1 did not fully restrain Youth B, but just
4

placed his hands on her wrists as she tried to swing at Staff 1.
Staff 2 stated that he would have assisted in a standing restraint
but right at the same time that Supervisor 1 made physical contact
with Youth B was when she went to the ground with knee pain and
stopped resisting staff’s directives.
Documents reviewed:
• Therapeutic Crisis Incident Report dated 01/29/2023
regarding the incident between Youth B and staff. This
report contains information consistent with youth and staff
interviews in that it states Youth B attempting to get to Staff
1 and being held back by Supervisor 1 and then injuring her
knee. It does not contain any narrative about any of the
verbal interactions that were alleged between Youth B and
Staff 1.
• Email communication between facility staff outlining
medical attention provided to Youth A on the evening of
01/29/2023. Over the counter pain medication and ice
were provided and instructions to take Youth A to be seen
for further medical attention the next day if any pain
continued in the morning or if she could not sleep.
• Covenant HealthCare documentation dated 01/30/2023
regarding Youth A’s knee injury. No fractures or dislocation
noted and Youth A was provided a knee brace and
crutches as a precautionary measure and instructed to
continue using over the counter medication to help with
pain and swelling.
• Therapeutic Crisis Intervention training materials that are
used by the facility were reviewed. This is the chosen
restraint model for the facility. Staff are trained to attempt a
standing restraint as the first physical management
technique, and in doing so the first contact they have with a
youth is to “grasp the young person’s arms above their
wrist with their outside hand.” This method is consistent
with what was reported of Supervisor 1’s physical contact
with Youth B during the incident in question.
Analysis Through face-to-face and phone interviews with staff and youth
and documentation reviewed, there is evidence to support a
violation of the rule due to language used by Staff 1 directed
towards Youth B.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4431 Heating equipment.
Section (1) Heating equipment shall be capable of maintaining a
Description temperature of not less than 68 degrees Fahrenheit at a point
5

4 feet above the floor. An accurate thermometer shall be
provided.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth at facility have asked staff to turn air conditioning on instead
of the heat, but staff turn the heat on in the night instead. Youth
report difficulties breathing when heat is on.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 01/31/2023 during an
unannounced face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth
A/Complainant stated that she struggles to breath at night
because the thermostat is turned so high. She knew that it was
set to 72 degrees because she often heard staff talking about it.
Youth A stated that she hadn’t heard that the thermostats had
ever been turned any higher than that in her time placed at the
facility. Youth A was asked if she took any medication or had any
medical issues that could contribute to feeling hot at night or the
difficulty sleeping, and she remarked that she did not. Youth A
was also asked if she was under any sort of safety planning that
might affect what items she can have at night and she did not.
Youth A believed that some, but not all of the other youth in her
unit had the same concerns as her. Youth A remarked that her
experience with the heat had only started recently.
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E were spoken to separately
during the same unannounced face-to-face visit to the facility on
01/31/2023. Youth F was spoken to on 02/10/2023 during an
announced visit to the facility. All five-youth had consistent
responses to the allegations that the unit was too hot at night to
sleep and stated that they had not experienced that. All youth
stated something to the effect of the temperature in the units being
consistent at night and that it had not prevented them from
sleeping. Multiple youth had stated that at times they had safety
plans in place that caused them to have less or specific blankets
and that they had felt warm enough sleeping even in the winter
months.
Therapist was interviewed on 02/10/2023 during an announced
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated that the units were
having new locked covers installed over the thermostats in order
to prevent discord surrounding the temperature in the units, and
that supervisors would have the keys to these boxes. One of the
units had this already installed and it was viewed.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews of youth and staff there was no
evidence found of a rule violation regarding the temperature of the
units at night.
6

Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the license remain unchanged upon acceptance of an
approved CAP.
